rules.rule_name: You Gotta vs You've Got vs You Have

structure.you_have: Formal - Standard English (You have to go)

rules.explanation_en: Three ways to express obligation or necessity with different levels of formality. 'You have' is standard formal English. 'You've got' is informal but acceptable in conversation. 'You gotta' is very informal slang (contraction of 'got to') used in casual speech but should be avoided in writing.

structure.can: Ability, Permission, Possibility (I can swim / Can I go? / It can be difficult)
structure.must: Strong Obligation, Necessity, Logical Deduction (You must study / It must be true)
structure.might: Possibility, Uncertainty, Permission (formal) (It might rain / Might I ask?)

rules.explanation_en: Modal verbs that express different levels of ability, obligation, and possibility. 'Can' shows ability or asks permission. 'Must' indicates strong obligation or certainty. 'Might' expresses possibility or uncertainty (weaker than 'may').

examples: Ability: I can speak three languages.
Permission: Can I use your phone?
Possibility: Learning English can be challenging.
Strong Obligation: You must wear a seatbelt.
Necessity: We must finish this today.
Logical Deduction: She must be tired after working all day.
Possibility (uncertain): It might rain tomorrow.
Polite Suggestion: You might want to check your email.
Formal Permission: Might I suggest an alternative?
Negative: You can't park here. / You must not smoke here. / It might not work.
Past: I could swim when I was young. / I had to study. / It might have been true.
rules.note: ğŸ’¡ Tip: 'Can' is more common than 'may' for permission in modern English. 'Must' is stronger than 'should'. 'Might' is less certain than 'may'.

rules.rule_name: We Gotta vs We Got vs We Have vs We've Got

structure.we_have: Formal - Standard English (We have a problem / We have to go)
structure.we_ve_got: Informal - Conversational (We've got a problem / We've got to go)
structure.we_got: Informal - Possession only, NOT obligation (We got a new car - past tense)
structure.we_gotta: Very Informal - Slang/Spoken obligation only (We gotta go - spoken only)

rules.explanation_en: Four different ways to express possession or obligation with varying formality levels. 'We have' is standard formal English for both possession and obligation. 'We've got' is informal but grammatically correct for both. 'We got' is ONLY for possession (often past tense) and NEVER for obligation. 'We gotta' is very informal slang for obligation only (contraction of 'got to'), used in casual speech but should be avoided in writing.
rules.explanation_es: Cuatro formas diferentes de expresar posesiÃ³n u obligaciÃ³n con diferentes niveles de formalidad. 'We have' es inglÃ©s formal estÃ¡ndar para posesiÃ³n y obligaciÃ³n. 'We've got' es informal pero gramaticalmente correcto para ambos. 'We got' es SOLO para posesiÃ³n (a menudo pasado) y NUNCA para obligaciÃ³n. 'We gotta' es argot muy informal solo para obligaciÃ³n (contracciÃ³n de 'got to'), usado en habla casual pero debe evitarse en escritura.
examples: Possession (formal): We have three children.
Possession (informal): We've got three children.
Possession (past): We got a new house last year.
Obligation (formal): We have to leave now.
Obligation (informal): We've got to leave now.
Obligation (slang): We gotta go! (spoken only)
WRONG: We got to leave now. âŒ (Use 'We have to' or 'We've got to')

Common mistake: Don't confuse 'we got' (past possession) with 'we've got to' (obligation)
rules.note: âš ï¸ IMPORTANT: 'We got' = past possession ONLY. For obligation, use 'we have to' (formal), 'we've got to' (informal), or 'we gotta' (slang/spoken). Never use 'we got to' for obligation - it's grammatically incorrect.

rules.explanation_en: 'Ever' has multiple uses in English: 1) In questions about life experiences (Have you ever...?), 2) With negatives for emphasis (don't ever, never ever), 3) In comparatives (more than ever), 4) In conditionals (if you ever), 5) With superlatives (best ever), 6) For emphasis in questions (Why ever...?). It generally means 'at any time' or 'at all times'.

rules.explanation_en: SAY is used to express words or statements. It does NOT take an indirect object directly after it. TELL requires a person (indirect object) immediately after it. SAY focuses on the words spoken; TELL focuses on the person receiving the information.
